causes: Economic hardship due to overpopulation and famines.
Discontent with Qing corruption and foreign influence after the Opium Wars.
Hong Xiuquan's religious movement claiming to establish a Christian 'Heavenly Kingdom' in China.
events_leading_up_to_war: 1843: Hong Xiuquan has visions declaring himself the brother of Jesus.
1850: Qing government cracks down on Taiping followers.
1851: Taiping forces defeat Qing troops and declare the 'Heavenly Kingdom' in Nanjing.

result.general: Qing Dynasty victory (with heavy foreign military support).
result.territorial_changes: Complete destruction of the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom.
political_changes: Qing Dynasty implemented **military and administrative reforms**.
Rise of **regional warlords**, weakening central authority.
Increased **foreign control over China**, as Western nations exploited Qing vulnerability.

Qing_Dynasty: Zeng Guofan (Qing general, architect of victory)
Frederick Townsend Ward (American mercenary leader of the Ever Victorious Army)
Charles 'Chinese' Gordon (British commander of the Ever Victorious Army)

Taiping_Heavenly_Kingdom.troops: Up to 2 million at its peak
Taiping_Heavenly_Kingdom.navy: Captured Qing vessels, limited naval strength
Taiping_Heavenly_Kingdom.weapons: Primarily traditional weapons, some Western firearms

Qing_Dynasty_and_Allies.navy: Qing fleet and Western naval support

major_battles.name: Siege of Nanjing
major_battles.description: Taiping forces captured Nanjing and made it their capital, holding it for over a decade before the Qing recaptured it.
major_battles.outcome: Qing victory, destruction of Taiping capital.

major_battles.name: Battle of Shanghai
major_battles.description: Western-backed 'Ever Victorious Army' crushed Taiping forces attempting to take Shanghai.

major_battles.name: Battle of Anqing
major_battles.description: One of the largest battles, Qing forces retook Anqing, cutting off Taiping supply lines.
major_battles.outcome: Qing victory, start of Taiping decline.

historical_documents.name: Taiping Religious Edicts
historical_documents.details: Documents where Hong Xiuquan declared himself the brother of Jesus and justified rebellion.

historical_documents.name: Qing Military Records
historical_documents.details: Detailed accounts of battles, casualties, and strategies used by the Qing forces.

archaeological_evidence.description: Weapons, remains, and fortifications from major battles like Nanjing and Anqing.
Unique currency issued by the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom.

political: Qing Dynasty **weakened**, leading to further instability.
Rise of **regional warlords**, undermining central power.
Foreign influence over China increased, setting the stage for the Opium Wars and later the fall of the Qing.
long_term_effects: One of the **deadliest conflicts in history**, shaping Chinese modern history.
Showed the **power of private militaries**, with the Ever Victorious Army influencing later Chinese warlord armies.
Contributed to Qing Dynasty's **eventual collapse** in 1912.

military: Early use of **Western-trained private mercenaries in China**.
Massive, prolonged guerrilla and conventional warfare.
economic: Massive economic devastation, especially in southern China.
Increased foreign trade as Qing sought Western support.
cultural: Religious aspect made it unique among civil wars.
Legacy remains in modern Chinese historical narratives.
